_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Roadrunner Gas Processing Plant
Executive Summary

Targa Northern Delaware LLC, owner and operator of the Roadrunner Gas Processing Plant, is committed to protecting the health and safety of company personnel, contractors working in the facility, our neighbors in the surrounding community and the environment.  This commitment is strongly supported by senior management and is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as employee training and in considering safety in the design, installation, operation, and maintenance of our facility. The facility does not anticipate having any type of uncontrolled release.  However, if an uncontrolled release does occur, the personnel at the facility will evaluate the situation, take actions within the capabilities of the facility, and notify the necessary outside agencies.

Description of the Stationary Source and Regulated Substances

The operation of the Roadrunner Gas Processing Plant is intended to process 880 MMscfd of gas. The gas will be treated to remove CO2, H2S, dehydrated to remove water and processed to remove heavy (liquid) hydrocarbons from the gas stream. Several plant systems will be involved to perform these functions. 
The facility consists of the following: inlet gas separation and filtration, molecular sieve dehydration, condensate stabilization, amine gas treating, glycol dehydration unit, cryogenic processing unit, refrigeration system, flash gas compression, residue compression, hot oil system, VRU compressor, flare system, and all associated utilities and ancillary systems. Condensate recovered from inlet gas is stored in five 1000-bbl atmospheric tanks located within secondary containment areas and loaded into tanker trucks for shipment. NGLs from the cryogenic unit and natural gas from residue compression are sent offsite via pipeline without intermediate storage.
The processes at the Roadrunner Gas Processing Plant are interconnected by piping and fit the EPA's definition of a st

ationary source in 40 CFR part 68. The facility contains one source of a regulated substance held over its respective threshold quantity; Flammable Mixture. 

OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS
Several storage vessels within the facility process were evaluated for the worst case and alternative release scenarios.  Results of the worst-case release scenario indicate that the process is subject to RMP Program Level 3 requirements.  Details of the release scenarios are included with the backup documentation associated with this RMP plan.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM
This facility is regulated by 29 CFR 1910.119 (Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals - PSM), 1910.38 (Employee Emergency Plans), as well as other federal, state and local regulations which are in place to reduce the potential for the release of Highly Hazardous Chemicals.

This facility has implemented the PSM elements to facilitate accidental release prevention.  Process safety information, consisting of technical standards, specifications and levels, promotes safe process design and operation.  Process hazard analysis evaluates hazards against safeguards needed to mitigate likelihood of an accidental release. Process changes are managed through the management of change procedure, by considering the impact that a change will have on the rest of the process.  For new or significantly changed processes, a pre-startup safety review is conducted as a final check to enable safe start up.  

The employee participation program promotes the development of necessary expertise, experiences, judgment, and proactive initiative within the workforce.  A comprehensive training program ensures that employees are knowledgeable about the processes they are responsible to operate and control.  Operating procedures explain correct startup, operation and shutdown procedures for various equipment in the process.  The hot work program is in place to promote safety of jobs involving potential ignition source

s.  The mechanical integrity program ensures that equipment is maintained inspected and tested for ongoing safety.  A contractor safety evaluation program is in place to ensure hire of contractors that will not compromise job or facility safety.   

The facility has a policy of investigating every incident, which may have possibly resulted in a release, in order to prevent a similar accident from recurring.  The facility has established an audit procedure to assure the continued integrity of the prevention program.  

5 YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
The facility has not had any RMP-reportable accidents within the last five years.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM
This facility is a non-responding facility and has coordinated with the local fire department for response to large, non-incipient stage, accidental releases.  As a non-responding facility, the RMP emergency response program and emergency response plan requirements (40 CFR 68.95) are not applicable at this facility.  However, the facility does maintain an emergency response plan that serves as guidance for facility employees to notify first responders, secure critical operations before evacuation, evacuate the facility, and account for personnel, among other items.  Facility personnel are trained in procedures and use of equipment appropriate to their role in response to small incipient accidental releases.

MANAGEMENT SYSTEM
The Area Manager has overall responsibility for the development, implementation, and integration of the risk management program at this facility.  Specific responsibilities are summarized in the backup documentation associated with this RMP plan.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
Facility personnel are continually developing new ways to improve the safety of the facility.  This is done through responsibility matrices and training which is a vital part of any safety program.  Training is conducted according to a systematic schedule.  All new and modified equipment is designed with appropriate safety
